title: Organic Compound for Light-Emitting Device and Organic Light-Emitting Device Using the Same
abstract: Disclosed is an organic compound represented by a general formula (I) comprising a bicarbazole core linked to a substituted aryl or heteroaryl group through a phenylene bridge. In the general formula (I), the bicarbazole core consists of two carbazolyl moieties connected at the 3-position of each carbazolyl unit, wherein one nitrogen atom of the bicarbazole core is substituted with a group selected from phenyl, naphthyl, biphenylyl, and pyridinyl, and the other nitrogen atom is substituted with a group Ar₁ which is a C₆-C₃₀ aryl group or a C₂-C₃₀ heteroaryl group optionally substituted with one to four substituents R₁ through R₄ independently selected from hydrogen, C₁-C₁₂ alkyl, C₆-C₁₈ aryl, and C₂-C₁₈ heteroaryl. The compound exhibits a triplet energy (T₁) of 2.75 eV or higher, a HOMO energy level between -5.6 eV and -6.2 eV, and a glass transition temperature (Tg) of 150°C or higher, making it particularly suitable as a host material in the emitting layer of blue phosphorescent and thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) organic light-emitting devices. Also disclosed are organic light-emitting devices incorporating the compound as a host material in the emitting layer, the devices exhibiting external quantum efficiency (EQE) exceeding 22%, CIE y-coordinate below 0.15, and operational lifetime (LT95) exceeding 500 hours at an initial luminance of 1000 cd/m². A method for fabricating such devices by vacuum thermal evaporation is also provided.

description.technical_field: The present invention relates to organic compounds suitable for use in organic light-emitting devices (OLEDs), and more particularly, to bicarbazole-based compounds having high triplet energy and excellent thermal stability for use as host materials in blue phosphorescent and TADF OLEDs.
description.background_summary: Blue organic light-emitting devices remain the bottleneck in full-color OLED displays due to the difficulty of achieving simultaneously high efficiency, color purity, and long operational lifetime. Host materials for blue emitters require a triplet energy (T₁) above 2.75 eV to confine triplet excitons on the dopant, a balanced charge transport capability, and high morphological stability (Tg > 130°C) to prevent crystallization-induced degradation. Conventional host materials such as CBP (4,4'-bis(N-carbazolyl)-1,1'-biphenyl) suffer from insufficient triplet energy (T₁ = 2.56 eV) and low Tg (62°C), leading to poor device performance in the deep blue region.

key_paragraphs.content: The 3,3'-bicarbazole core was selected as the central scaffold because the meta-linkage between the two carbazolyl units effectively disrupts π-conjugation, resulting in a high triplet energy while maintaining adequate hole transport capability through the nitrogen lone pairs.

The introduction of heteroaryl groups such as dibenzofuran-4-yl and dibenzothiophen-4-yl at the N₁ position provides additional steric bulk that raises the glass transition temperature above 150°C without significantly lowering the triplet energy.

Density functional theory (DFT) calculations at the B3LYP/6-31G(d) level confirmed that the HOMO is primarily localized on the bicarbazole core while the LUMO is distributed over the Ar₁ substituent, enabling independent tuning of hole and electron injection barriers.

description.examples_summary: The specification provides 5 synthesis examples (Compounds 1-5) and 2 comparative examples (CBP and mCBP). Each compound was synthesized via Suzuki-Miyaura or Buchwald-Hartwig coupling, purified by column chromatography and sublimation, and characterized by ¹H NMR, ¹³C NMR, MALDI-TOF MS, DSC, TGA, and UV-Vis/PL spectroscopy. OLED devices were fabricated with the structure ITO/HAT-CN(10nm)/TAPC(30nm)/Host:FIrpic 15wt%(25nm)/TmPyPB(40nm)/LiF(1nm)/Al(100nm) and characterized for EQE, current efficiency, power efficiency, CIE coordinates, and operational lifetime (LT95 at 1000 cd/m²).

molecules.name: Compound 1
molecules.synthesis_reference: Suzuki-Miyaura coupling of 9-phenyl-3-(4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-1,3,2-dioxaborolan-2-yl)-9H-carbazole with 9-(4-bromophenyl)dibenzofuran-4-yl carbazole intermediate. Yield: 62%.

molecules.name: Compound 2
molecules.synthesis_reference: Buchwald-Hartwig amination of 3-bromo-9-phenylcarbazole with 4-aminodibenzothiophene followed by ring closure. Yield: 55%.

molecules.name: Compound 3
molecules.synthesis_reference: Two-step synthesis: (1) Suzuki coupling of 3,3'-dibromo-bicarbazole with biphenyl-4-boronic acid; (2) Buchwald-Hartwig amination with 3-aminopyridine. Overall yield: 48%.

molecules.name: Compound 5
molecules.synthesis_reference: Buchwald-Hartwig amination of 3-bromo-9-phenylcarbazole with 2-amino-9,9-dimethylfluorene, followed by intramolecular cyclization. Yield: 45%.

molecules.name: CBP (Comparative)
molecules.location_in_patent: Comparative Example 1, Column 23, Lines 10-30; Table 2, Row 1
molecules.synthesis_reference: Commercially obtained from Sigma-Aldrich (purity >99.5%, sublimed grade).

molecules.name: mCBP (Comparative)
molecules.location_in_patent: Comparative Example 2, Column 23, Lines 35-55; Table 2, Row 2
molecules.synthesis_reference: Commercially obtained from Lumtec (purity >99%, sublimed grade).

test_conditions.measurement_method: calculated from HOMO and optical band gap

prosecution_history.description: Utility patent application filed under 35 USC §111(a) as national stage entry of PCT/KR2021/007892

groups_identified.description: Organic compound per se (claims directed to the compound of Formula I)
Organic light-emitting device (claims directed to device structure)
Method of fabricating device (claims directed to manufacturing process)

details.basis: The inventions are distinct because the compound of Group I can be used in applications other than the specific device of Group II or made by methods other than Group III. The device of Group II can use host materials other than the compound of Group I.

prosecution_history.description: Applicant elected Group I (compound claims) with traverse to Groups II and III without prejudice

details.traverse_arguments: Applicant respectfully traverses the restriction requirement on the grounds that the compound claims, device claims, and method claims are sufficiently related that a search for one would necessarily encompass a search for the others. The shared technical feature of the bicarbazole compound of Formula (I) constitutes a special technical feature that makes a contribution over the prior art.

prosecution_history.description: Non-Final Office Action rejecting claims 1-15 under 35 USC §103

details.rejection_summary: Claims 1-8 are rejected under 35 USC §103 as being unpatentable over Kim (US 10,256,419 B2) in view of Lee (US 10,892,421 B2). Claims 2, 9-12 are rejected under 35 USC §103 as being unpatentable over Kim in view of Lee and further in view of Park (WO 2019/182285 A1). Claims 3, 13-15 are rejected under 35 USC §103 as being unpatentable over Kim in view of Lee and further in view of Tanaka (JP 2019-156832 A).

cited_references.title: Bicarbazole compounds for organic electroluminescent devices
cited_references.relevance: Primary reference. Discloses 3,3'-bicarbazole core structure with aryl substituents on nitrogen atoms. Teaches use as host material in blue OLED devices.

cited_references.title: Organic light-emitting device with carbazole-based host material
cited_references.relevance: Secondary reference. Teaches the use of heteroaryl substituents (dibenzofuranyl, dibenzothienyl) on carbazole-based host materials to improve thermal stability and triplet energy.

cited_references.title: Novel organic compound and organic light-emitting device comprising same
cited_references.relevance: Teaches specific OLED device architectures using carbazole-based host materials with HAT-CN/TAPC/TmPyPB auxiliary layers.

cited_references.title: Method for manufacturing organic electroluminescent device
cited_references.relevance: Teaches vacuum thermal evaporation co-deposition methods for forming emitting layers with specific temperature and rate parameters.

objections.description: Claim 7 is objected to for reciting functional limitations (T₁ ≥ 2.75 eV, Tg ≥ 150°C) without sufficient structural basis in the claim language to distinguish over the prior art.

prosecution_history.description: Applicant's response to Non-Final Office Action with claim amendments and arguments

amendments.amendment_summary: Independent claim 1 amended to specify that the 3,3'-bicarbazole core has a specific connectivity pattern wherein the two carbazolyl units are bonded exclusively at the 3-position (not 2-position or 1-position), and to add the limitation that Ar₁ is a C₆-C₃₀ aryl or C₂-C₃₀ heteroaryl group containing at least one heteroatom selected from N, O, and S (narrowing from the broader original scope). Independent claim 2 amended to specify that the emitting layer comprises the compound of amended claim 1. Claim 7 amended to include structural basis for the functional limitations by specifying that the compound has a molecular weight of 500 or greater.

arguments.argument_summary: Applicant argues that the combination of Kim and Lee does not render the claimed invention obvious because: (1) Kim discloses only 2,2'-bicarbazole and 2,3'-bicarbazole linkages, not the specific 3,3'-bicarbazole linkage of the present invention, and the 3,3'-linkage provides unexpectedly superior triplet energy (2.75+ eV vs. 2.55-2.65 eV for 2,2' and 2,3' isomers); (2) Lee's teaching of heteroaryl substituents is directed to monocarbazole compounds, and one of ordinary skill would not have been motivated to combine Lee's heteroaryl substituent teaching with Kim's bicarbazole core because Lee teaches away from bicarbazole structures due to their synthetic complexity; (3) The claimed compounds exhibit unexpected results in the form of simultaneously achieving T₁ > 2.75 eV, Tg > 150°C, and EQE > 22%, which is not predictable from the prior art.

declarations_filed.summary: Declaration providing comparative experimental data showing that 3,3'-bicarbazole compounds of the present invention exhibit 15-25% higher EQE and 5-7x longer device lifetime compared to structurally analogous 2,2'-bicarbazole and 2,3'-bicarbazole compounds disclosed in Kim (US 10,256,419).

prosecution_history.description: Final Office Action maintaining rejection of claims 1-6, 8-15 under 35 USC §103; withdrawing rejection of claim 7

details.rejection_summary: The examiner acknowledges the amendment to claim 1 narrowing Ar₁ to heteroaryl groups but maintains that the combination of Kim and Lee still renders claims 1-6 and 8 obvious because Lee explicitly discloses dibenzofuranyl and dibenzothienyl substituents on carbazole nitrogen atoms. The examiner finds the unexpected results argument partially persuasive for claim 7 (which now includes structural and functional limitations) but not for the broader claims 1-6 and 8. Claims 2, 9-12 and 3, 13-15 remain rejected as dependent on claim 1.
response_options: File Request for Continued Examination (RCE) under 37 CFR §1.114
File appeal to Patent Trial and Appeal Board (PTAB)

prosecution_history.description: Request for Continued Examination (RCE) filed with amended claims

amendments.amendment_summary: Independent claim 1 further amended to incorporate the limitations of original dependent claims 4 and 5, narrowing Ar₁ to 'selected from the group consisting of dibenzofuran-4-yl, dibenzothiophen-4-yl, biphenyl-4-yl, and 9,9-dimethylfluoren-2-yl' and Ar₂ to 'phenyl or pyridin-3-yl'. Original claims 4, 5, 6, and 8 cancelled as their limitations are incorporated into amended claim 1 or rendered moot. Claims renumbered: original claims 1, 2, 3, 7, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15 become new claims 1-11 (but original numbering maintained in prosecution record).

arguments.argument_summary: Applicant argues that the amended claim 1 now recites a specific and narrow combination of structural features (3,3'-bicarbazole core + specific Ar₁ heteroaryl/aryl groups + specific Ar₂ groups) that is not disclosed or suggested by the combination of Kim and Lee. Kim does not disclose 3,3'-bicarbazole with dibenzofuranyl or dimethylfluorenyl substituents. Lee's teaching of these substituents is limited to monocarbazole scaffolds. The combination of the 3,3'-bicarbazole core with these specific substituents produces synergistic effects (high T₁ + high Tg + balanced charge transport) that are not predictable from either reference alone.

prosecution_history.description: Notice of Allowance and Fee(s) Due for claims 1, 2, 3, 7, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15

details.reasons_for_allowance: The prior art of record, taken alone or in combination, does not disclose or suggest the specific combination of a 3,3'-bicarbazole core with Ar₁ selected from dibenzofuran-4-yl, dibenzothiophen-4-yl, biphenyl-4-yl, and 9,9-dimethylfluoren-2-yl, and Ar₂ selected from phenyl and pyridin-3-yl, as recited in amended independent claim 1. The applicant's comparative data demonstrating unexpected improvements in triplet energy, thermal stability, and device performance over the closest prior art compounds is found persuasive.

fees.notes: First maintenance fee window. Due 3 years 6 months after grant date.
Second maintenance fee window. Due 7 years 6 months after grant date.
Third and final maintenance fee window. Due 11 years 6 months after grant date.

a_delay.description: Delay due to failure of USPTO to take certain actions within 14 months of filing

b_delay.description: Delay due to failure of USPTO to issue patent within 3 years of filing

c_delay.description: Delay due to interference, secrecy order, or appellate review

overlap_reduction.description: Reduction for overlapping A and B delays

jurisdiction_rules.revival_deadline_description: Petition to revive must be filed within 24 months of the date the patent expired for failure to pay maintenance fee, or within the period of the unintentional delay, whichever is later.
